rights and environmental protections and by enhancing the role of Parliament in the next phase of negotiations I believe we can reach a deal that this House can support.Talks are continuing apace between the UK and EU, with Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay and Mrs Mayrsquos de facto deputy, David Lidington, meeting MEPs in Strasbourg on Tuesday.Mr Barclay was said to have held ldquoconstructive talks on Monday night with the EUrsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels.The pair agreed to further meetings in the coming days, while their teams will continue to work to find a way forward.Meanwhile, Sky News reported the former president of the European Council, Herman Van Rompuy, had dinner with Mr Lidington in Brussels on Monday night.Mr Van Rompuy has been tipped as a potential ldquoinfluencer to break the Brexit deadlock, the broadcaster reported.Negotiations of a kind have also been taking place back in Westminster, with an exchange of letters between Mrs May and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.However a Cabinet minister insisted there is ldquono chance of Mrs May accepting Labourrsquos vision for leaving the EU, despite speculation she could soften her stance on customs union membership.In an exclusive interview with the Press Association, Commons leader Andrea Leadsom dismissed the prospect of Mrs May adopting Mr Corbynrsquos ldquoworld view.Mrs Leadsom, an ardent Leaver, said she would stay in the Cabinet to help Mrs May deliver Brexit and denied that the PM was softening her stance over a customs union in a letter to Mr Corbyn.Mrs Mayrsquos reply sparked concern among Conservative Brexiteers that the Prime Minister could concede too much ground to Labour in an attempt to win cross-party backing for a deal with Brussels.Mrs Leadsom said: ldquoI think shersquos making quite clear that what Corbyn is demanding is actually not as good as what the Prime Ministerrsquos deal is offering.ldquoSo he wants a customs union and he is unclear as to whether that means he also wants an independent trade policy.ldquoHersquos unclear as to whether he also wants to stop free movement, and of course the EUrsquos view would be, lsquowell,yoursquore in the customs union then you have free movement and you abide by the common external tarfrsquo.ldquoI think therersquos no doubt that what the Prime Minister is offering is better than what Corbyn is demanding, which simply begs the question,they like it, why donrsquot they vote for it Mrs Leadsom said there was ldquono chance Mrs May would adopt Mr Corbynrsquos ldquoview of the world, adding: ldquoThe Prime Minister has been absolutely clear wersquore leaving the EU, wersquore leaving the customs union, wersquore leaving the single market.The frontbencher refused to say what the cut-off date would be for the necessary legislation to get through the Commons to allow the UK to leave the EU as planned on March .She said it was possible to pass bills ldquoquite quickly with ldquogoodwill from the Commons and Lords, but added: ldquoItrsquos just not possible to say how quickly it could be done.

title: global-quest-to-bring-32-radiologists-to-scotland-recruits-just-five-and-one-was-already-here
story: One of the doctors hired was already based in Scotland, and a second was lured from England - but only on a locum contract.Five of the nine participating health boards did not recruit a single new radiologist as a result of the initiative.Read more: Staff crisis means Highland patients travelling to Grampian and Tayside for emergency radiologyThe campaign was launched by then Health Secretary Shona Robison in February  with promises of "targeted advertising across the globe", and a recruitment focus geared to Western Europe, India, Australia, the USA and Canada.At the time, Ms Robison said it would "highlight the benefits of living in Scotland and working for our NHS", adding that the Scottish Government was "determined to recruit and retain the best and the brightest".However, figures obtained by the Herald under freedom of information reveal that one year on only five consultant radiologists have been hired.NHS Dumfries and Galloway had the greatest success, recruiting one permanent consultant radiologist and one on a fixed-term contract. A third is expected to begin work in the region later this year, pending approval from the General Medical Council.NHS Lanarkshire appointed one full-time radiologist - although the doctor was already in Scotland - and NHS Forth Valley recruited an Indian-born consultant radiologist, who had previously been working in England, on a locum basis.NHS Grampian said it has made one "offer of employment", but the post is not yet filled and it is unclear whether it will be.NHS Tayside, Fe, Highland, Greater Glasgow and Clyde, and Ayrshire and Arran had no success finding candidates.Read more: NHS Scotland spends poundm sending cancer scans to private firms in UK and overseasDr Grant Baxter, the Glasgow-based chair of the Standing Scottish Committee of The Royal College of Radiologists, said: ldquoThe international recruitment campaign was a laudable initiative but has, by anyonersquos standards, been very disappointing."Diagnostic and interventional radiology demands continue to increase in Scotland, with at least one-in-six consultant posts empty."We fully support the Governmentrsquos aims of earlier cancer diagnosis, improved treatments and outcomes and the establishment of le-saving interventional radiology techniques such as stroke thrombectomy - but signicantly more radiologists are required to achieve them."Read more: Stroke patients left signicantly disabled amid lack of stroke thrombectomy proceduresRadiologists play a crucial role in the timely and accurate diagnosis of cancer by analysing CT and MRI scans for signs of disease.Shortages have been blamed as a factor behind spiralling referral-to-treatment waiting times for cancer patients.In the past decade, vacancies for consultant radiologists have nearly tripledin NHS Scotland, from  to .Around  in every  posts was empty, around  of them vacant for six months or more. In NHS Fe, vacancies have gone from one to  in a decade.Although a shortage of radiologists is being experienced UK-wide, leading clinicians say they have been warning the Scottish Government for at least  years that the crisis was looming.They say they were left frustrated that money was not ploughed in sooner to fund extra traineeships for junior doctors wanting to specialise in radiology, especially as the number of suitable candidates has consistently outstripped the number of available places.On average, for every four people who apply, only one gets taken on.In , the Scottish Government finally pledged pound million to fund an extra  extra trainee radiologist places over five years, but it is still considered far short of the number needed.Dr Baxter added: ldquoThe only reliable and guaranteed solution is to train more radiologists."Hundreds of young doctors apply and many are unsuccessful due to lack of available posts."Ironically, the vacancy crisis does not mean there are fewer radiologists working in Scotland.In fact, the number of consultant radiologists is at a record high of  - up % in  years. However, demand for radiology has grown exponentially as the population ages and cancer incidence grows.Meanwhile, France has nearly three times as many radiologists per person than the UK, and Germany and Spain both have around twice as many.Gregor McNie, Head of External Affairs said: ldquoWith an ageing population, more people being screened and a focus on early detection, shortages in the cancer workforce will become an ever growing problem unless this is addressed now.Scottish Conservative shadow health secretary Miles Briggs said radiologist shortages are "acute" in some areas, adding: ldquoThe fact theSNP government has failed so miserably to attract sufficient numbers is deeply disappointing."Scottish Labour shadow health secretary Monica Lennon called on Health Secretary Jeane Freeman to "get to grips with the growing staffing crisis in our hospitals.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoRadiology continues to experience acute shortages worldwide, which is why we have taken action to both increase training places and improve recruitment."By  we will have increased specialty training places in radiology by approximately % from  levels.ldquoThe international radiology recruitment campaign, launched in , generated interest from clinicians around the globe. Health boards are now finalising a number of offers of appointment.NHSGreater Glasgow and Clyde stressed that while they did not fill any posts through the official global recruitment drive, they had hired  radiologists through their own training programme and were "actively trying to recruit a further five".A spokeswoman said: "Eight were appointed last year and a further two were appointed in January."Although we did not appoint anyone through the global recruitment drive we did recruit the new radiologists as part of our successful training programme with trainees coming to Glasgow from across the world."To have secured ten clearly shows that, as a Board, we are viewed as an attractive and prestigious employer."

title: Iain Macwhirter  After making demands she couldn t accept  Corbyn has made Theresa May an offer she can   t refuse
story: Last week, Corbyn made a remarkable overture to the Prime Minister. He effectively dropped his opposition to her Withdrawal Agreement, which Labour had repeatedly condemned as the ldquoworst of all worlds. The Labour leaderrsquos letter still calls for a customs union, regulatory alignment on trade and guarantees on workers rights and security cooperation. But, crucially, Labour is no longer holding to the ldquosix tests, and insisting a Brexit deal should deliver ldquoexactly the same benefits as being in the single market.Labour has even dropped its opposition to the Irish backstop, which Mr Corbyn condemned, as recently as December, for leaving Britain ldquoin an indefinite halfway house with no say on its future. The explanatory note that Labour circulated after the leaderrsquos letter to May is quite clear. ldquoAny withdrawal agreement," it says, ldquowill need to include a backstop." Labour is also hinting at further compromises in ldquonegotiations.Hitherto, Labourrsquos policy has been to make demands May could never accept now they are trying to make her an offer she canrsquot refuse.So at last, after months of there being nothing much new to say about Brexit, suddenly we have what looks like a breakthrough, a historic compromise. Of course, you canrsquot overestimate the ability of political leaders to look a gt horse in the mouth. Theresa May may be so wedded to being a ldquobloody dficult womanthat she may find a way to avoid accepting Labourrsquos free hooved mammal. But the deal is there to be made.Senior Tories like Sir Oliver Letwin have welcomed the Labour offer, seeing it as a step towards a Norway-style agreement, even though it isnrsquot. Labourrsquos plan is much closer to Turkey, which is also in a customs union and accepts regulatory alignment. Brussels likes Corbyns proposals too, as a way out of hard Brexit ldquohell.Ive argued that the logic of Labourrsquos position was always to back something resembling Theresa Mayrsquos deal with the EU. It corresponds to Labourrsquos manesto commitments to leaving the EU, including the single market, and ending free movement while seeking frictionless trade. Mrs May has always supported regulatory alignment, since the ldquocommon rule book in her Chequers plan. And the backstop, remember, involves the UK remaining in the customs union until there is a future comprehensive trade deal.In what could almost have been a coordinated intervention last week, Mrs May restated in Dublin her determination to prevent a hard border in Ireland. This put the wind up the DUP, since they fear that the border might now move to the Irish Sea.It didnrsquot appeal to the hardline Brexiteers in her own party either, who are adamant that no deal is better than her bad deal. They thought it had been killed off by last monthrsquos record-breaking Commons defeat ndash but it may now live again with Labourrsquos backing.They canrsquot admit it, of course, but May and Corbyn are now speaking broadly the same language. The customs union, regulatory alignment, rights and protections etc are all matters to do with the future trade relationship with the EU, not the Withdrawal Agreement. It covers only money, citizenship and the Good Friday Agreement.The trading relationship can only be negotiated after Brexit. It is to be hammered out within the up to four years of the transition period, during which the UK remains in the single market and the customs union.Onlythere is no agreement does the backstop comes into play, and that really just extends the transition period indefinitely. May has said she will get assurances that the backstop will be time-limited, but she canrsquot get that from the European Union. If it was limited, it would no longer be a backstop.What hard Brexiteers really fear is that the transition period might lead to a soft Brexit, not a clean break ndash and they are right. What we know is that MPs will block any no-deal Brexit. Hardliners face a choice of May Corbyn or no Brexit at all.To secure a Commons majority without them, Mrs May could promise legislation to keep Britain in regulatory alignment with the customs union until a new trade deal is finalised ndash one which delivers the same benefits. This is anyway implicit in her promises to keep trade ldquofrictionless. Indeed, remaining in a customs union is the only way of achieving this. Up to now, she hasnrsquot been able to say this openly for fear of a rebellion by her hardline backbenchers, led by Jacob Rees-Mogg. They want a managed no-deal now, or in four years, under the so-called ldquoMalthouse Plan.Butshe has an ounce of political sense, May will now face them down and pivot to Labourrsquos softish Brexit. Labourrsquos demand that she put the customs union in primary legislation can be finessed, because the trade negotiations canrsquot happen until after Brexit. She doesnrsquot even need to ensure that Labour votes with her. Labour could abstain in the meaningful vote and achieve essentially the same result. The DUP would accept the customs union as a guarantee against a backstop or an east west hard border.Jeremy Corbyn could explain Labourrsquos abstention, which will be attacked by Vote Leave MPs andleader writers, by saying, as his spokespeople did last week: that the top priority ldquofor the nation is to avoid a no-deal. Corbynite commentators can be relied upon to condemn any Labour MPs who continue to vote against Mayrsquos deal as traitors. Unreconstructed Blairites, voting with the hated Moggists to force a no-deal disaster.Corbynrsquos letter made no reference to a Peoples Vote. Remainers in the Labour Party realise where all this is heading, which is why a number, like former shadow cabinet figures like Owen Smith, and Clive Lewis, have threatened to leave the party. That could become part of the script.Corbyn has used the Brexit issue to smoke out Blairite Remainers like Chuka Umunna, and the Jewish MP, Luciana Berger, in order to portray them as disloyal splitters.Of course, ordinary members of the Labour Party will be mightily confused. Many of them still think Labour is committed to a referendum. It still could come to that, of course,May doesnrsquot seize this opportunity.I still harbour vague hopes that A could be revoked, but Irsquom afraid that pro-Europeans are on the wrong side of history right now. The country is destined to leave the EU, because letrsquos face it, Labour under Jeremy Corbyn is and has always been a pro-Brexit party.And after Brexit Day  Well, get ready for Groundhog Day  as negotiations over the future EU trade deal begin all over again.

title: labour-push-to-end-brexit-delay
story: Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said his party will use a Commons amendment this week to make the Prime Minister hold another ldquomeaningful vote by February .He said he wanted to stop her ldquocynical and ldquoreckless plan to run down the clock before March  then present MPs with a stark last-minute choice between her deal and no-deal.There is a suspicion Mrs May wants to wait until after a summit of EU leaders on March .Labourrsquos move prompted Number  to offer MPs another vote on Brexit options by the end of the month, but only a non-binding one.Business leaders attacked the uncertainty and said it was making no-deal more likely. CBI boss Carolyn Fairbairn said the UK was now in the Brexit ldquoemergency zone.Labour MPs Pete Kyle and Phil Wilson proposed a new way out of the impasse: support for Mrs Mayrsquos deal infor a referendum on it. If the deal was rejected, the UK would stay in the EU on current terms.The idea, which avoids a no deal, is backed by Tory Remainers Sarah Wollaston, Dominic Grieve and Anna Soubry. It is intended to unite Remainers and Leavers, although the latter remain intensely suspicious of another referendum.The police officer leading on Brexit also warned no-deal would make the UK less safe.Deputy Assistant Commissioner Richard Martin said the inability to check the names of suspected criminals on EU databases as fast meant a ldquoreal risk of people absconding.ldquoEvery fall-back we have is more bureaucratic, it is slower, he saidMrs May is due to update MPs on Wednesday on the progress of talks with Brussels about making changes to the Irish backstop part of her Withdrawal Agreement.With EU leaders refusing to reopen the deal, she is expected to say more time is needed for negotiations, and table a ldquoneutral motion the following day, which Labour wants to amend to force a meaningful vote on February .Accusing the PM of ldquopretending to make progress in order to bounce MPs into backing her deal over no-deal, Sir Keir told the Sunday Times: ldquoWe have got to put a hard stop into this running down the clock.He said: ldquoThere needs to be a day when Parliament says thatrsquos it, enough is enough.He also called Mrs Mayrsquos approach reckless and blinkered, and blamed her ldquotunnel vision for her losing the first meaningful vote on her deal last month by a record  votesldquoItrsquos this blinkered approach thatrsquos got us to where we are, with her never wanting to see where the real majority is in Parliament, he said.In response, the government promised another opportunity to table amendments on February , but failed to commit to a binding vote on the deal itself by the end of the month.Communities Secretary James Brokenshire said: ldquoThat gives that sense of timetable, clarity and purpose on what we are doing with the EU - taking work forward and our determination to get a deal - but equally knowing that role that Parliament very firmly has.LibDem leader Sir Vince Cable said delaying the final vote on the Brexit deal was ldquoworse than irresponsible and said Mrs May ldquofaces a massive rebellion by Conservative MPs.Tory MP Heidi Allen said it was ldquocompletely irresponsible to keep delaying and urged ministers to ldquostep up this week and end the risk of a No Deal Brexit.Mrs May also played for more time in her reply to Labour leader Jeremy Corbynrsquos proposal for a soft Brexit compromise.She said she was ldquonot clear about his call for a customs union, but wanted more talks she rejected his plan for the UK automatically following EU rules on workersrsquo rights and environmental protection, and said Parliament should decide what to follow instead.It came as Tory activists warned Mrs May she would suffer heavy Tory losses in Mayrsquos local elections south of the bordershe committed the ldquounforgivable betrayal of a customs union.Labourrsquos internal problems were highlighted by deputy leader Tom Watson, who admitted he was worried about a breakaway party.He also confirmed Labour was investigating the Liverpool Wavertree branch over the ldquobullying of Jewish MP Luciana Berger, a frequent victim of anti-Semitic abuse.Local pro-Corbyn activists, including one who called Ms Berger a ldquodisruptive Zionist, had tabled no confidence motions in the MP, before withdrawing them last Friday. Mr Watson had called for the branch to be suspended, but Labour general secretary Jennie Formby refused, saying there was no constitutional basis for doing so. Former PM Tony Blair said Labour had not been ldquorobust enough in tackling anti-Semitism, and said what has happening to Ms Berger was ldquoshameful for the Labour Party.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford urged Scots Labour MPs to oppose any Brexit deal, calling Mr Corbynrsquos compromise a ldquodevastating blow to communities.He said: ldquoIt is alarming that, despite the overwhelming damage that the Prime Ministerrsquos deal will cause to Scotland, the Labour Leader would seek to support the deal. Scotland did not vote for Brexit and our nation must not be dragged out of the EU against our will.ldquoI call on Scottish Labour MPs to reject the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, support the SNPrsquos calls for an extension to Article  and back a second referendum on EU membership.In her reply, Shadow Scottish Secretary Lesley Laird accused Mr Blackford of ldquooutright fabrication and political opportunism.She said: ldquoOur proposals provide a constructive way out of this mess. It beggars belief that you would prefer to indulge in brazen political posturing, aiming your fire at Labour as a constructive opposition, rather than the shambolic Tories.ldquoIt is hypocritical of you to express concerns about the economic challenges from Brexit while at the same time agitating for independence for Scotland. I believe that it is incumbent on all of us to ensure that we do not fan the flames of ision but instead genuinely attempt to unite the country.

title: highland-games-to-introduce-non-binary-categories
story: The Scottish Highland Games Association , which represents more than  Games north of the border, met yesterday to discuss non-binary representation.The countryrsquos main Highland Games body has faced strongcriticism over its lack of gender equality for female athletes and is under pressure to include transgender non-binary categories in its events.The move towards making Games more inclusive follows last monthrsquos announcement by Scottish Athletics that all its championship events would include a non-binary gender category.The Scottish K Championships at Silverknowes, Edinburgh, in April, will be one of the first such events.The SHGA, established in , met in Perth to discuss the development of strategies on both gender equality and non-binary representation and will meet the Scottish Government this month to lobby for funding.Ahead of yesterdayrsquos meeting, SHGA secretary Ian Grieve sent committee members an email about demands to allow women to compete in the Games, highlighting the link to Scottish Athleticsrsquo new policy on non-binary categories.He said: ldquoWe donrsquot have an official policy view on non-binary events, but we may discuss it. It is definitely going to get more complex. There might even be other categories out there as well.ldquoScottish Athletics are being a wee bit progressive ndash good luck to them.The first historical references to the Highland Games heavy eventswere during the reign of King Malcolm III between  and .The Ceres Games in Fe are the oldest continuous running Highland Games, established in  by Robert the Bruce.In December, Rhoda Grant, Labour MSP for the Highlands and Islands, saidorganisers wanted Scottish Government funding they would need to be seen as an organisation treating people as equals.James Morton, manager at Scottish Trans Alliance, said: ldquoHighland Games should showcase positive traditions but not out-dated sexist exclusion.ldquoWith such a wide range ofHighland Gamesrsquo events, including tossing the caber, running, Highland dancing and solo piping, there doesnrsquot need to be a one-size-fits-all approach.ldquoFor example, it may turn out that all bagpipers could compete against each other regardless of sex gender, while for running events the Highland Games might wish to choose to adopt the same inclusion policies as ScottishAthletics."For heavy events such as tossing the caber and tug o war, it may turn out that fairness and safety of competitors means grouping based on physical characteristics such as height and or weight and lting ability rather than sex gender.He added: "We hope the Scottish Highland Games Association will embrace bringing these exciting Scottish traditional sports to ever wider audiences and erse competitors."The basic vital step of including women competitors should clearly be the top priority."

title: new-tinder-style-app-for-farm-animals-in-the-moo-d-for-love
story: A new matchmaking app pairing up farm animals is also set to launch on February , offering breeders the chance to swipe right for the perfect partners for their cattle .The Tudder app works in the same way as Tinder, allowing farmers to use their smartphones to look at the profiles of cows and bulls from , farms across the UK.And while the app - created by the SellMyLivestock website - might appear to be a bittongue in cheek, the launch is part of a push to reinvent the way farmers trade and breed animals.Jamie McInnes, co-founder and chief technology officer of SellMyLivestock, said: "Finding the right match can be daunting for us humans, let aloneyoursquore a four legged farm animal."Traditionally, playing moo-pid for cows would require proper grafting: visiting each herd of hopefuls at dferent farms, or at an auction market, all the while running the risk that the best cow on the market has simply slipped past you."And while this is a bit of fun on Valentinersquos Day, it highlights how relevant online matchmaking is for farmers looking for breeding livestock."Buying breeding cattle is now enabled by a huge amount of genetic data to create the perfect match. This is the equivalent of a human online dating profile, except it is validated in science rather than a self proclaimed GSOH ."Traditional livestock trading can be very labour intensive, with farmers travelling long distances to sell their products at market.But there us often no guaranteed buyer and a lack of transparency when it comes to pricing.SellMyLivestock believe online trading could help to transform cattle farming and make it a lot easier for breeders to buy and sell animals.To use the Tudder app, farmers will first have to indicatethey are looking for a cow or a bull before scrolling through profiles and swipe right for yes - with mooing sound as they do - or swipe left for no.Once a match has been made, farmers will be redirected to the SellMyLivestock website where they can browse photographs and learn more about the breeding stock listed.If they are interested in the livestock featured, they can then contact the owners to agree a price.Tudder is available to download via the app store on both Apple and Android.

title: new-lord-of-the-rings-tv-series-to-be-filmed-in-scotland
story: Skye, Loch Lomond and Perthshire have all been tipped as potential filming locations for the poundbn series.:Lord of the Rings map annotated by JRR Tolkien for sale at pound,According to reports, production crews looked at locations such as Portree, Dunskey Castle and Portpatrick in the south-west and Scourie in the north-west have all been earmarked as potential locations.Callander in Perthshire and Balloch Castle Country Park have also been visited.The prequel from Amazon Studios to JRR Tolkienrsquos trilogy is set to have the biggest budget in television history, with the series set to be shown in .Filming is set to begin this year afterAmazon paid pound million for the global rights to Lord of the Rings.Amazon Studios head Jenner Salke said of the series:ldquoWersquore not remaking the movies, but wersquore also not starting from scratch. Itrsquoll be characters people love. Therersquos no shortage of ambition for the project.:Its official: climate of Tolkiens Middle Earth is...like LincolnshireThe filming in Scotland comes following a number of successful productions in the last few years withthe likes of Avengers: Infinity War, the Fast and Furious filmsand Netflix historical drama Outlaw King all having been recently been shot here.Filming in Scotland has brought in signicant amounts for the Scottish economy with more than pound million brought into the economy of both Glasgow and Edinburgh from filming in .Despite the reports, the filming has not been confirmed by Amazon.

title: call-to-cash-in-on-the-harry-potter-railway
story: Famed for its spellbinding scenery and the iconic Glenfinnan viaduct, the West Highland Railway has become an international tourist attraction after doubling for the route taken by the Hogwarts Express in the film adaptation of JK Rowlings novels.Now Scotrail is being urged to cash in on the soaring numbers of passengers on the line, which runs from Glasgow to Fort William and onto Mallaig, by putting on extra services and providing a better experience for tourists.And a fresh injection of funds could also be magic for those travelling the A by easing congestion on the road to the Isles.Fresh figures published by the Office of Rail Regulation have revealed that the number of people travelling on the "Harry Potter" railway has doubled in the past decade, while hundreds are travelling to the countryside nearby to watch the train as it crosses the bridge.And the line - previously been hailed as one of the most scenic in the world - continues to be a runaway success, with the latest statistics show that the number of passengers passing through Fort William station growing by ,between  and last year.:Police issue warning to viaduct touristsThe numbers arriving at Glenfinnan station follow a similar track, rising by almost , while those reaching Mallaig are up by , or  per cent.Annual passenger numbers have increased by almost , passengers across the area, with growth at other towns such as Aviemore, Dingwall and Kyle of Lochalsh also appearing in the figures.Kate Forbes, MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch constituency, believes that now is the time to capitalise on the popularity of the enchanting route.She said: ldquoItrsquos fantastic to see more people choosing to go on the lsquoHarry Potter linersquo and experience the fantastic scenery at the Glenfinnan viaduct, as well as the breath-taking views from Fort William to Mallaig generally.ldquoUltimately, I would like to see more people using public transport instead of driving as it reduces congestion and its good for the environment. That means that public transport needs to be reliable, comfortable and regular.ldquoI would like to see ScotRail invest more signicantly on this line, and capitalise on the clear growth in tourism the area is experiencing. Strategically, especially given the frequent delays with Fort William traffic in the peak summer months, it makes sense to get more people off of the road and onto trains.Kate Forbes,MSPThe West Highland Railway is  miles long and runs by Loch Long, Loch Lomond and Loch Eil, passing the silver sands of Morar.Ms Forbes added: ldquoSeeing passengers up by over , in Fort William and also by nearly , in Mallaig is absolutely brilliant.:From Bond to the BFG - on the Scottish film set trailldquoFor a relatively small fishing village like Mallaig where parking is under pressure, that is a colossal increase and I hope that local shops and businesses have felt the benefit of the rise in visitors.ldquoIf demand continues to grow, ScotRail and Network Rail should invest more so that visitors and locals alike can enjoy the beauty of the West Highlands.Filming of s Harry Potter and the Chambers of Secrets and Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, released in , took place at Glenfinnan. In real-le, the Express is the Jacobite steam train.The viaduct is the largest concrete railway bridge in Scotland and was opened in . It crosses the River Finnan at a height of  feet and overlooks Loch Shiel and the Glenfinnan Monument to the Jacobite rebellion of .More than , visitors flocking to Glenfinnan Station in -, and ScotRail has announced it will build a new footpath to help handle the volume of people.Boy Wizard Harry Potter takes the train to school each yearMeanwhile, a walkway that crosses the hillside between the railway station and the viaduct will be upgraded to provide easier access to several new viewing areas, allowing tourists to capture the stunning scenery.:Potter fans boyfriend proposes aboard the Hogwarts Express.The project will be a working partnership between ScotRail, the West Highland Community Rail Partnership , Glenfinnan Station Museum, Glenfinnan Estate, Network Rail and Transport Scotland.It is hoped the work helps to increase the proportion of visitors arriving by public transport by improving the facilities available.ScotRail project manager Anouska Chisolm said: "The new footpath and viewing areas at the Glenfinnan Viaduct will be fantastic for tourism in the area and we hope it will encourage more visitors to travel here by rail instead of car."Its important that we continue to work with our key partners on how we can boost tourism and bring wider economic benefits along Scotlands most scenic railways."

title: business-diary-of-nicola-sturgeons-top-aide-records-gym-class-but-not-alex-salmond-meeting
story: Official logs show Liz Lloyd enjoyed an early morning fitness class on April , while a work catch-up meeting scheduled for later that afternoon was cancelled.But the diary, released under Freedom of Information, makes no mention of a meeting between Mr Salmond and Ms Sturgeon at the latterrsquos house in Glasgow that same day, despite Ms Lloyd also being present.:Calls for public inquiry into "unlawful" handling of sexual misconduct complaints against Alex SalmondIt was during this meeting that Mr Salmond first told his successor he was being investigated by the Scottish Government amid allegations of sexual harassment.A spokesman for the Scottish Tories said: ldquoPeople will certainly have questions to ask about the diary of a senior taxpayer-funded Scottish Government employee.ldquoThe SNP Government does not have to wait for the Holyrood investigation, and could clary exactly what this member of staff was doing on these days, and why.Entries in Ms Lloydrsquos business diary covering the dates of phone calls and meetings between Ms Sturgeon and Mr Salmond were released following an FoI request.It comes amid intense scrutiny of the contacts, during which Mr Salmond brought up a Government investigation into sexual harassment allegations against him.:Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond at war over poundk legal caseThe meetings are set to be probed by MSPs after questions were raised over Ms Sturgeonrsquos involvement and her initial decision not to report the contact. She insists it was not government business.It previously emerged Ms Lloyd helped set up the meeting on April . However, her business diary shows no record of it ndash but takes time to log a fitness ldquoboot camp at .am.Mr Salmond appeared in court last month charged with two attempted rapes, nine sexual assaults, two indecent assaults and one breach of the peace. He strongly denies any criminality.A Scottish Government spokeswoman said Ms Sturgeon had set out her position, and it would not be appropriate to comment further.

title: bid-underway-to-turn-scots-power-station-site-into-cruise-ship-port
story: Now a bid is underway to transform a landmark former power station into a new port to take advantage of the countryrsquos booming cruise liner business ndash and have a multi-million-pound impact on Scotlandrsquos food and drink exports in the process.:Isle of Arran is Scotlands first plastic-free communityFigures from trade body Cruise Scotland for last year show a . per cent year-on-year rise in passenger numbers to ,, with an .% increase in ships to .And experts say Scotland is now recognised as the second largest growth market globally for the cruise industry.Prestonpans Community Council is promoting the transformation of the former Cockenzie Power Station, which was decommissioned in March , into a new port.It is backed by transport consultant Roy Pedersen, who invented the road equivalent tarf, or RET, the new fare structure designed to ensure crossing water is no more expensive than driving the same distance.Mr Pedersen, who serves on the Scottish Governmentrsquos Expert Ferries Group, said the -acre Preston Links site, now owned by East Lothian Council, has a number of advantages that would make it a top spot for cruise ships, including a sheltered location with deep water close to shore, ready access to the main navigation fairway and no height restrictions.He also believes the port offers the potential for reinstating a Scotland-continent ferry link, estimating up to , jobs would be generated directly and indirectly from the whole project.He said: ldquoA further advantage of the new port is that once cruise ships can be berthed alongside, the port is strategically well placed as a cruise turn-around port, which means that the job-generating business of crew change and supplying vessels with food and other necessities presents a signicant economic opportunity.ldquoTypically, a , passenger cruise ship requires about pound million worth of supplies for one weekrsquos cruising, of which a substantial proportion is food and drink, thereby contributing to Scotlandrsquos food and drink exports.Calum Miller, a member of Prestonpans Community Council, said one of the factors driving the bid is the attraction of Edinburgh as a cruise ship ldquohoneypot destination. In a blog, he added that at the core of the problem are Victorian port facilities that canrsquot scale to handle the bigger cruise liners.He said: ldquoThese ships canrsquot limbo under the Forth bridges to visit Rosyth, nor squeeze into Leith docks. Instead, passengers are force-ferried on small tenders to South Queensferry or Newhaven harbour.Rob Mason, head of Cruise for Capital Cruising, Forth Portsrsquo cruise business, said, though: ldquoWe are extremely proud of our cruise business.ldquoWe are seeing our passenger numbers grow each year, through investment in our facilities and we continue to seek opportunities across the Forth to accommodate the increase in demand from larger cruise liners.The key feature of the proposed new port is a simple finger pier, with sufficientand depth alongside to accommodate the largest cruise ships and a berth for a cruise ferry to provide a nightly service to the continent.A similar finger pier at Tallinn, Estonia, was built for just pound million though a more extensive pier and related terminal land at Hatston near Kirkwall cost between poundm and poundm.:Highland port to undergo poundm revamp to welcome worlds biggest cruise shipsMr Miller said: ldquoWith a little dredging and investment, the biggest ships could soon be gliding alongside a more modern quay with professional facilities. This new terminal would have the capacity to act as a home port, increasing the inidual passenger spend in the Lothians to pound.Based on bookings, around , liners are heading for Scottish ports this year, with passenger numbers expected to be up by .% at more than ,.Mr Pederson added: ldquoIf handled skilfully, Scotland has the opportunity to reap huge economic benefit from a modern low carbon cruise and ferry port that will transform both our access to continental markets, but will create a world ferry and class cruise turn-around port that is so lacking at present.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoA port for cruise is one of a number of ideas that have been promoted for the site. Technical work would be required to determine viability including a port engineering study, an environmental assessment and an economic analysis.

title: letters-bias-has-now-become-part-of-the-ethos-of-the-bbcs-question-time
story: The "non-political" lists are frequently even more extreme in their views, particularly over Brexit, and far more aggressive in putting forward their view. That someone should be a member of the audience on dferent occasions should surprise no one, as the main concern of the producers is viewing figures, and these are boosted by having controversy, not by providing information.On the issue of bias, it is, sadly, there and seems part of the ethos of the programme. On Question Time a few days before the EU referendum, both David Dimbleby and Chris Grayling were out of their chairs to correct a lady who referred to "English values", pointing out that the said values were in reality "British". This political correctness did not long survive the vote, and not one on the  a few weeks later corrected an audience member who referred to "English industry and trade".Having watched the decline in standards over the past  months, I have decided not to waste my time watching Question Time. If I want to hear a reasoned and intelligent political discussion, I will ask a group of teenagers their opinion.T J Dowds,q Fleming Road, Cumbernauld.I NOTE with interest Mark Smiths article. I have thought for some time that Question Time has lost its way and that we no longer are presented with considered debate from reasonably informed members of the public. It seems to be a perpetual shouting joust from hand-picked members of the public. Last weeks episode was the prime example, no proper debate. I find now, and have done for some time, that I can only tolerate about half the programme before retiring with a good work of fiction.On Thursday evening the five members of the audience who were invited to participate, before I switched off and went to bed, were all vehemently opposed to the SNP, including as Mr Smith pointed, out one who was a Ukip member of the Orange Lodge, entitled to his opinion, however unchallenged in the "debate".In his last few years I felt David Dimbleby had lost control and Fiona Bruce, his replacement, whom I admire as a newsreader and presenter, lacks the incisive qualities of, for example, Emily Maitlis, who has proved on Newsnight she has the ability.The same  participants also seem to appear every few weeks asthe BBC has a limited pool of participants. Time for the BBC to review where this once-great programme is heading, or has the Brexit issue finally brought it to the point of no recovery Wallace Milligan, Juniper Green, Masonhill, Ayr.MARK Smithrsquos assessment of the BBCrsquos Question Time in Motherwell was charitable indeed. He gives the BBC the benefit of the doubt after allowing a known Ukip activist his fourth opportunity to shout at the SNP on the programme. This love-in between the BBC and Ukip has been longstanding, given the number of appearances Nigel Farage has had on the programme in recent years.The continued and sustained lack of SNP politicians appearing despite being the third largest party at Westminster compares badly with the treatment of the Liberal Democrats when they were in an identical parliamentary position. The truth is that the BBC has failed in its service to Scotland. The pound million Scotlandrsquos licence fee payers send south should instead be used to fund a new BBC Scotland, with complete editorial independence from the BBC in London. Before anyone complains that this would provide a poor service given a budget of this size, please be aware that Irelandrsquos BBC, which is known as RTE, spent eurom Ein .The New BBC Scotland would have at least the same spending power as RTE.Francis Buchan, Drybrough Crescent, Edinburgh.LAST Thursday on BBC Question Time from Motherwell, a serial audience member, former Ukip candidate Billy Mitchell, popped up in his favourite orange jerkin for his fourth appearance in so many years. This is a breach of the QT rules. A stooshie ensued on social media. Was he a far right plant by a Unionist-leaning editorial team, or had he sneaked in because of a flawed vetting procedure  I made it clear I thought cock-up, not conspiracy was the answer.That didnrsquot stop Mark Smith weighing in yesterday, writing a piece in which he described my position ndash that is, rejecting a conspiracy ndash as ldquocrappy, conspiratorial Da Vinci Code thinking. I know, surreal.Mr Smith also had an eccentric take on Mr Mitchellrsquos choice of orange jacket it was no more signicant than SNP list Fiona Hysloprsquos blue jacket. However a wee bit of googling would have alerted him to the fact that Mr Mitchell is a supporter of Ulster Young Militants, and calls himself "orange jacket man" on Facebook. So I donrsquot think itrsquos unreasonable to assume that his choice of jacket was a self-conscious sartorial nod.Why does it all matter  Well because Question Time producers say they have clear rules be up front about who you are when you apply to be on the programme, no repeat audience appearances, and politicians arenrsquot allowed to take cover in the audience ndash their place is on the  where they can be identied and their views subjected to scrutiny. Thatrsquos something surely we can all agree on John Nicolson,Presenter, TalkRadio, Hatfields, LondonAS they always do when theyre found out, Nationalists are claiming the Question Time audience was rigged and looking for dirt on Billy Mitchell. No wonder. The "Scotland is fed up to the back teeth of the SNP" genie was brutally hurled out of the bottle in front of millions of UK TV and social media viewers, never to .Mitchells final flourish: "Ye need tae get voted oot and leave Scotland tae prosper," was a clear challenge to opposition parties to up their game and finish the job in .Allan Sutherland, Willow Row, Stonehaven.Read more: Mark Smith on the Question Time row

title: yougov-poll-finds-snp-would-gain-four-seats-in-snap-general-election
story: According to the new poll, while the Scottish National Partys share of the vote was unchanged since  on %, but the YouGov model suggested they could boost their tally of Westminster seats by four to .:Brexit: Senior SNP source says Peoples Vote is deadThere was an overall drop for both the Conservatives and Labour.The YouGov survey for The Times found that Conservatives would increase their -seat tally by four to , with Labour shedding  MPs to end up with .While such a result would leave Mrs May short of commanding half of Parliaments  MPs, she could expect a wafer-thin working majority due to the fact that the Speaker and his deputies do not vote and Sinn Feins MPs do not traditionally take their seats.:Herald poll: Scotland should have independence referendum after BrexitIf Sinn Fein held on to its seven seats, Mrs May could expect a working majority of just one or two in the Commons and would be highly vulnerable to rebellions by backbenchers in her own party.In practice, she might well find herself once more dependent on the votes of the Democratic Unionist Party.The poll of more than , voters in England, Scotland and Wales used a model of assessing inidual constituencies which correctly predicted a hung Parliament in , when most pollsters were forecasting a comfortable Tory victory.It put Conservatives on % - down four points from the % recorded in British seats in  - but predicted a larger drop in support for Jeremy Corbyns Labour, down seven points from % in  to % now.Liberal Democrats were on %, up three points from the last election. And Ukip, which slumped to % in , experienced a resurgence to hit %, taking a signicant chunk of support from the Tories.YouGov questioned , British adults form February  to  and applied the results to the demographics of each inidual constituency to work out local swings.

title: craig ascends bennachie 100 times
story: A Kemnay man ascended Bennachie  times in just one year.Craig Thomson completed the achievement on Sunday, December , .His friend, Ross Henderson, joined Craig on the milestone expedition.Ross said: “I met Craig back in  and a few months after, he spoke about wanting to do Bennachie  times in a year.“The main motivation behind this was the memory of a friend of his, Malcolm, who died of Neuofibromatosis.“Malcolm succombed to the condition shortly after he and Craig had completed an ascent of Bennachie so it is entirely fitting that he should complete such a challenge.”“I quite often saw Craig’s car heading out towards Bennachie on many an occasion, sometimes when it was dark.“I did join him on a few expeditions out on the hill, one of them we timed well as we ed to the car park when it was dusky.“I hadn’t heard much from Craig until a few days before Christmas when he sent me a text askingI wanted to join him for the th ascent.“On the day a few of us met up at the back of Bennachie car park, there were  of us and three dogs so an excellent turnout.“He handed us all a program for the day which contained a written discription of his previous ascents and how he had built up to the full .“In  he managed  and in  he reached  and then stopped counting as it was getting late in the year.”The group set off and after an hour or so they had reached the summit of Oxen Craig, Bennachie’s highest peak.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! them.The £m project was completed last year and pupils have been at the school since August.During the building’s construction more than  pupils were taken by bus daily to nearby Midmill School for  months, following a fire in the old building back in .Temporary accommodation on site was made for the nursery children.The new library space at Kinellar SchoolThe new school is built on the same site as its predecessor. As part of the build, the project team used the opportunity to improve facilities in the village by redeveloping a derelict tennis court and constructing an enclosed children’s play park as well as additional parking for use by the school and local community.The school’s social staircase is already becoming a well-used architectural feature alongside its many other bright and airy flexible learning spaces, including the glass fronted library and learning area upstairs.Its teaching wings benefit from cleverly designed acoustics, modern set up and technology offerings in all  classrooms, and are on two levels, with lightwells connecting them.Specially commissioned artwork is also an important feature of the new school.Local artists worked with pupils to design and create a number of pieces, including a large Oak tree in the dining area symbolizing growth with leaves painted by every child.  Aberdeenshire Provost Bill Howatson said: “A great team effort has led to the delivery of an extremely high quality building on time and on budget, and we’re thankful to everyone who has played their part in that. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Erasums students question what will happen after Brexit"  What is the future for Erasmus students after Brexit  viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"“It stands testament to what a community can achieve by working together, right from those dark early days after the fire when local people rallied round to offer soup and sandwiches to staff, to the lovely reception pupils received from the community in Kintore.”Chair of Education and Children’s Services Committee, Councillor Gillian Owen said: “It’s not only wonderful to see the pupils at Kinellar enjoying their new school but also to reflect on what a fantastic learning experience this project has given them. In addition to the educational opportunities – working with artists, the community and the construction team – the pupils have also learned important lessons when it comes to being resilient and flexible.”Head Teacher Pamela Farquhar added: “As much as we loved our time at Kintore it is nice to be back home.“The new school was made possible thanks to Anne Gibson who sold her land to Aberdeenshire Council.“Her husband was a former head teacher here so the school has a special place in her heart.”

title: virtual subsea work for meldrum pupils
story: Meldrum Academy pupils have taken part in OPITO#s Energise Your Futureevent.The academy was one of eight north east schools to have taken part in the initiative that was held during the final day of Subsea Expo at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre on Thursday, February .EYF is managed by OPITO, the global, not-for-profit, skills body for the energy industry.The event aims to inspire and encourage more young people in the UK to consider the industry as a career choice by providing a chance to get up close with key companies and people who can help explain their businesses as well as roles and routes into the sector.This year,  companies were involved in the Subsea Expo programme.Marine engineering firm EC-OG offered pupils the chance to use its latest virtual reality technology which will transport them subsea to inspect its subsea power hub and battery equipment.John McDonald, OPITO CEO, said: “As more and more oil and gas companies embrace new techniques such as virtual reality and articial intelligence, it is important that young people see and hear first-hand what the future of the industry looks like and the vast and exciting opportunities these developments present to them.”Attracting young talent remains a key focus for the sector.The recent OPITO UKCS Workforce Dynamics Review showed thatthe sector achieves its ambitions set out in Vision ,, people will need to be recruited over the next two decades.Around , of those are expected to be in roles that don’t yet exist.Mr McDonald added: “We are currently developing a new UKCS Skills Strategy to support the skills that will be required by both new and existing personnel operating in the North Sea into the next decade.“It is important we provide opportunities through initiatives like EYF to help young people discover that this is a sector with a future worth considering that also has the learning infrastructure in place to help develop their career and unlock their potential.”The pupils taking part were all aged between  to . The other schools at the event were Aberdeen Grammar, the International School Aberdeen, Oldmachar Academy, Albyn School, Mintlaw Academy, Robert Gordon’s College and Peterhead Academy.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Jemima Adeoye, Director of Education and Childrens Services Laurence Findlay, Elizabeth Lyall, Cooper Masson, Cllr Gillian Owen, Cllr Jim Gford, Provost Bill Howatson, Chief Executive Jim Savege, Tami Fadeyi, Ruaridh Cumming and Head Teacher Pamela Farquhar with pupils outside the new Kinellar School"  Community celebrates official opening of Kinellar School viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: inspectors praise north east nursery
story: Education inspectors have expressed confidence in the ongoing improvements being made at Rothienorman Pre-School Nursery.A recent visit led to the village hall facility being described as a “welcome and nurturing environment” and Inspectors said children were “happy, enthusiastic, and developing confidence”.Key strengths included a “dedicated team” which inspectors said have developed positive relationships and a “strong sense of community”.But the nursery has been asked to improve in certain areas, including increased use of national guidance to develop a “robust and rigorous approach to self-evaluation”. Inspectors said this will enable practitioners to identy what is working well and what needs to improve.They also want to see development of approaches to assessment and planning to help improve the quality of learning experiences and provide “greater depth and challenge” for all children.Improvements are also being sought in the development of practitioners’ knowledge and understanding of how to support children’s early language and mathematical thinking.Inspectors are confident that the setting has the capacity to continue to improve and will make no more visits in connection with this inspection.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The group at the summit of Oxen Craig - Craig Thomson is pictured th left"  Craig ascends Bennachie  times viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: to move or not to move that is the brexit question
story: Should people hold off putting those for sale signs up until the summer To move or not to move A study by the HomeOwners Alliance found that just  per centof people said their decision to stay where they are was based on concerns over Brexit, with more popular answers relating to lack of suitable homes and property prices.Russell Quirk said: ldquoThis research shows that Brexit isnrsquot the driving factor behind many UK home sellers looking to move or stay put and while we have seen the market slow due to the uncertain future of our partnership with the EU, the market is showing positive signs of recovery across the board.ldquoWhile this may strengthen once a Brexit deal is finalised there is no guarantee as to the outcome, and so those looking to sell should rest assured that now is as good a time as any to sell their home and later might not necessarily be better.Property commentator and buying agent Henry Pryor told the HomeOwners Alliance that he didnrsquot think that Brexit would have an impact straight away.ldquoJust like New Years Eve  when people wonderedplanes would fall out of the sky ortheir microwave would stop working because of the Millennium Bug I expect that March  will have a similar effect.ldquoWho seriously lsquoknowsrsquo what the impact of our actual orce from Europe will be ldquoThe three Drsquos will continue to provide a supply of sellers over the next year ndash death, debt and orce wonrsquot wait for Mrs May and Co to sort this out but there will be far fewer buyers who lsquomustrsquo purchase.ldquoAs a professional buyer, I am expecting to be especially busy as the more squeamish buyers ask for help making what in more normal times might be considered insulting offers. Brexiteers may claim that like other lsquoProject Fearrsquo predictions the anticipated damage to house prices has not been felt but I suspect they will be a bit more muted in a years time.If the Government negotiates a deal with the EU before March nothing will change until December , .The overriding answer seems to be that there is too much uncertainty at the moment soyou feel it is the right time to move, do it.Read more: Should I renew my EHIC card or will Brexit make it invalid data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carricktoday webimage ..! title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: This weeks Caithness Courier
story: Due to circumstances beyond our control, this weekrsquos edition of the Caithness Courier wonrsquot be in the shops until Thursday morning. We apologise for any inconvenience but this was due to a combination of problems with our contract printers and distribution partners.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Tuesday  Feb  : AM

title: bus feedback events to return
story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. The events are open to everyone and will be held in Kirkwall and Stromness.The events give everyone the opportunity to provide feedback on what is working and what doesn’t about the local bus service. Representatives from Stagecoach will also be present to hear feedback on the services provided on the island.Greig Mackay, deputy director for Bus Users Scotland said: “We are looking forward to ing to Orkney to hear the views of the bus passengers. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”The two meetings will take place, later this month. Firstly, at Kirkwall Travel Centre on Monday, February , pm-pm, and then in Stromness on Tuesday, February , am-.pm.David Liston, managing director for Stagecoach North Scotland added: “We always welcome feedback on the services we provide and there is no better way to gather this than to host an event in partnership with Bus Users Scotland.#The feedback we received last year really helped us to develop improvements across the island demonstrated by the enhancements we made to services throughout the summer in .
